answers.answer: RP is usually fairly easy to diagnose.  you either have the signature "bone spicule" pigmentation of RP or you dont.  you must not have bone spicules or your ophthalmologist would have said something.you cannot diagnose yourself with RP.  just b/c you think you have trouble seeing at night does not mean that you have RP.  a new diagnosis of RP in a 32 year old would be shockingly rare...most RP cases are diagnosed before the age of 20.

Thanks Doctor. You are the best! All of these eye problems I have been experiencing lately have made me a bit of a hypochondriac. I've been misdiagnosed on other health issues, and find myself not trusting. I appreciate your advice.

question: Hi Doctor,When walking into a completely dark room, I cannot see a thing.  What happens is after a couple of seconds, my vision starts to fade to black.  If my eyes move, then I can see, but if I stare without moving them, it's total darkness. My day vision is fine, I have no peripheral loss etc., and I can see fine in dim light too.I recently saw a Retinal Specialist post-laser of a retinal break, and he said that my retina's look great for someone who has had type 1 diabetes for 20 years (I am 32 years old). There were small traces of retinopathy but he had to look really hard to find them.I am scheduled for an ERG in a few months, and he told me that he doesn't think it's necessary, but to do it anyway since I've got the appointment.My question is: are there other signs that an ophthamologist can see on the retina that would indicate RP? If not, he mentioned it could be the diabetes doing this, but not to worry, it's not sight threatening.What are your thoughts?
title: Retinitis Pigementosa?
